title: Why are they mad? A look into the motivations of angry, shouting champions.
body:
With the writing of Aatrox's lore (note: not _re_-writing; the Darkin weren't a solid idea before), there have been a number of complaints about him being changed from a quiet, mysterious character to an angry rampaging demon. And while I won't go into detail about how the mysterious character didn't go with his visuals, playstyle, animations, or abilities, I want to point out his and other champions' _reasons_ for being angry. I hope these short explanations shed at least a little light on the mindset of these characters. 

In order of my opinion on the magnitude of their reason:
{{champion:421}}  First things first, as for the "angry for the sake of being angry" nonsense I've seen claimed, Rek'sai is the _only_ example. She's angry because she's motivated entirely by predatory instinct. She, unlike Rammus, is an animal in body and mind. 
{{champion:240}} A sociopath. He isn't just telling everyone to get off of his property as a joke; he truly believes all of Runeterra is his. He defends "his" land from anyone in sight with all the ferocity of an old coot with a shotgun who thinks you're stealing his peaches. 
{{champion:23}} Revenge for his clan. Simple enough. 
{{champion:57}} Speaks for the trees, and the trees are not happy to be destroyed by magic. 
{{champion:58}} Driven mad by his incarceration.
{{champion:14}} Unwillingly brought back from death into a body that has _no feeling_, with little memory of the man he once was. 
{{champion:19}} His body was torn apart and reshaped into that of the monster we see in game, anesthetic intentionally withheld to drive his sanity further away. 

{{champion:266}} And then there's Aatrox:
Following his descent from a godly hero of justice, he was sentenced to a fate far worse than any hell I can imagine. Instead of the mercy of a quick death, he has endured millennia with no body and no senses of _any_ kind. 

As you can tell, I ranked it mainly based on the pain which caused their anger, from the complete lack of pain present for Rek'sai, to the emotional pain of Tryndamere, to the intense physical and mental pain of Warwick. Aatrox stands at the top because he has the most reason to be angry: Loss of a clan? How about an empire. No feeling? At least Sion can move and see. Physical pain? The body of every host rejects him to the point that the blood, bones, and muscles tear away from each other. 

*****
In conclusion, champions are not made angry just for the sake of having an angry character. They're made angry because it fits the story.

There was legit no good to old Aatrox. He was a murderhobo who jumped into random wars he had no stake in for the purpose of killing people and driving others to commit atrocities, he was legit nothing but evil. There's nothing that indicates any care for a cause or how just the side he's helping is. Yeah he helped the underdogs, but he only did it to prolong wars and suffering. Hell, if anything by helping the people who should've failed in the battle, he's simply prolonging the war and loss of life. Not to mention the whole bit where he slaughters Tryn's tribe for no reason

Mystery isn't a character design, it's a character flaw. 

I've pointed it out before on other threads, but the only reason he was mysterious is because they hadn't actually written the Darkin into the story. 

You ask all those questions, now you have the answers. 

And I'd wager to say no, current Aatrox is not full-bown evil, and certainly not as evil as the old Aatrox. The only, only thing we knew about old Aatrox was that he delighted in causing and prolonging wars. I'd call that evil. 

New Aatrox wants his suffering to end, and unfortunately is unable to die. He wants to bring an end to everything in hopes that he will also cease to exist. And he isn't motivated by causing others to suffer.
 
It may just be my own experience with suicidal people, but all I can see is a man who needs help. I can only hope that some time in the next year or two they do a huge lore event where the Darkin find out that Azir has in fact returned, and can redeem themselves.

While I agree that mistery is a flaw in character design, old aatrox had an interesting personality and philosophy. He saw war as a form of art. He had a somewhat detached and external approach to war. He inspired bloodlust in others but he was calm and poetic. That is very interesting and inspired to me.

My opinion is that new aatrox is much more cliche and unoriginal. "Angry because trapped" is legit and makes perfect sense, however it doesn't do justice to what Aatrox used to be. While new Aatrox might be good, more fleshed out, even better than the old personality-wise, he's to different and that is unacceptable to me in a rework. "Angry because trapped" also heavily homogenizes all the darkin's personalities, and that is a problem. Aatrox could have easily been the fallen ascended that, his own kind gone extinguished, turned to his new purpose of patronizing war and perfecting his own host.

Seems to me like you're equating lack of cohesion with originality. 
Sure, a spartan-armored clown with a strong sense of justice is original, but it makes no sense. 

Everything you listed that you clam to like about old Aatrox is directly opposed to his visuals, story, and playstyle. He wasn't a cohesive character. That personality would be suited to a cloaked, supportive mage rather than a demonic, basic-attack based diver. 

What Aatrox used to be was a cliche personality put onto the design for a totally different character.

I wouldn't say Aatrox's personality homogenize the personalities of all three Darkin. Varus is in a different situation, wherein both his hosts still have enough control to force him to fight for Ionia rather than simply kill humans. Rhaast, even when he takes control, is completely calm-- I'd say you got what you would've wanted from old Aatrox in Rhaast.

Why couldn't an immortal demon be calm and poetic? Why would it be "lack of cohesion", please elaborate. Especially considering that at the time darkins were nothing set in stone. 

His personality was perfectly in line with his previous story, I don't know why you don't think so. That said, there was a disconnection between personality+lore and gameplay: many expectations with the rework were, in fact, about expanding his inspirator role.

//

All darkins are very angry towards humanity and want to release destruction upon the world. 

I think you have never, ever played Raahst. "Completely calm". Lol. He's quite joyful and sarcastic about how he's going kill everybody, that's sufficiently different from Aatrox edgy rage I guess, but it comes off far from being "calm".

No, you misunderstand. It's not that an immortal demon can't be calm and poetic. Swain is exactly that, assuming his demon gives him longevity. As are Evelynn and Tahm Kench. 
It's not that a _demon_ can't be calm and poetic, it's that a character (demon or otherwise) can't dive headfirst into the fray, madly swinging a sword around to drink in the blood of his enemies and be calm and poetic at the same time. 

That's where the first disconnect lies: between the graceful, dance-like swordfighting in his lore and the mad hack-and-slash animations he had in game. 
The second is how his personality contradicts his story, particularly involving Tryndamere. Seeing as they're a clan of barbarians, what would stir them up and get their blood boiling is a loud, boisterous leader-- not a quiet dancer-like fencer. 
And needless to say those two aspects together; a majestic fighter and strong-but-quiet leader of armies, had no connection to his "jump on top of the enemies and right click like there's no tomorrow because Blood Well is up" style. 

Unfortunately they couldn't have very well expanded upon his role as an inspiration because they've been trying for years to dwindle the number of passive, unseen ally-boosting effects. Which is exactly what he would've needed to fit that thematic. 

//

As for Rhaast, you can be calm and joyful at the same time. The calm is in the delivery of the lines. He isn't overly angry, and he simply likes the killing. He doesn't seem to have the deeper motivation of revenge like Aatrox.

Look, I get your point but I think you entirely missed what was great about previous Aatrox.

He is immortal, thus he has participated to countless wars through the millennia. In such a being, there must be a **different perspective**, an historical one. He knows deeply what is war, why men fight and how to **move their spirits**. 

**He's not directly involved in the motivations of the war itself**; he could not care less about petty mortal squabbles. After so many, one war is just another one. He is not smitten by the supposed injustice of the opposite faction, he does not make his some ideal for which he fights.

What is the fervor of battle, to him? **How could he feel pathos when he cannot die, and everyone on the battlefield is much weaker than him?** There is no fear of death, nor there is the passion for challenging a worthy foe. 

So... Why does Aatrox fight? One motivation is the "Raahst way": "I fight because I like killing hehe XD". Don't get me wrong, that's fine. Makes sense. But it isn't that deep nor original.

Aatrox was something more: **he does not delight in the act of killing others**.  

Given his position in history and towards war, his approach to fighting must be **disinterested. He is an estimator of war, not a soldier.** He sees war as a form of art, and he meddles in human affairs with the sole purpose of witnessing men killing each other like beasts, **for he finds beauty in that**. 

**Love for own's concept of beautiful.**

That's what suistains his endless quest through the years.

That's his philosophy and his poetry.

That's where his calm is from. 

He's external to bloodlust, hate, and rage. Yet, to "paint a war" **requires those characteristics in the men that fight the battle**. His role as an artist is to **incite those in the hearts of the soldiers, not to feel them**. To him, men are instruments of a work of art. They are worth nothing past their instrumentality in being part of a bloody war. 

And so Aatrox **lies** to mortals. He lies when  he turns the tides of a battle, he lies when he speaks to the men he saves, he lies when he inspires them, he lies when himself descends to devastate his enemies. **Aatrox is a deceiver**.

A big part of his old VO was about finding motivations to fight ("fight not to be forgotten" etc.), just like he was trying to convince someone in joining the fray; the rest was praising war as a form of art.

I like him because his approach to war is radically different from the classical one, and it is not so straight forward. I found it rather unique.

Title: "Why are they mad? A look into the motivations into angry, shouting champions"

OP wanted to say a couple things about why some champions scream and are generally angry.

I wanted to throw in my 2 cents, by adding a couple champions who, to me, fit the angry shouting category. 

Syndra is shouty, not a lot, but by a fair amount. She also feels pretty angry. Whether that's beacuse she feels like she's alone against the world, or because she's, as you put it, an attention whore, that's up to debate at this point, since she's wasn't touched by the Ionia update. 


For me, it's hard to say if she's simply power drunk. Guy who was supposed to be her master was actually suppressing some of her powers; probably with good intentions, but it ended badly. 

So again, in response to your "lol what?", I say that for me, she's an angry shouty champions, because she thinks to be alone against the world. After that, you can say what you want, whether it's her being a total bitch, which is possible, or the world being scared of an indipendent ionian woman who don't need no man.
Aatrox is constantly shouting at me and I can barely understand one word in three, so I figure he's a Manhattan street vendor and his motivation is that he wants to sell me hot dogs.

To be fair, if I was going to think of someone in a similar predicament to Aatrox-- trapped in an unending hell without feeling hoping only for someone to force his essence upon-- it'd be a hot dog vendor.

Well here's kind of the obvious problem.

People respond differently to the same stimuli.  What makes one person a raging foaming at the mouth murderer, can make another react, well, not at all.

It's actually pretty easy to justify a lot of emotions to fit a story, if you know how to write it.  Actually we even see this in the Darkin themselves.  Rhaast and Varus both went through the exact same situation that Aatrox went through and they didn't turn into screaming lunatics.  Rhaast became a snarky narcissistic serial killer like figure, and Varus became filled with a desire to find his family.

Frankly, being stuck as a sword doomed to wander all eternity.  It is just as justifiable that Aatrox has grown empty over the course of his millennia, and strives to add chaos onto the battlefield because that is the only time he can truly feel anything anymore.  It would have fit much better with his old personality and still fit the new direction of the lore.

The writers just didn't want to do that though, and wanted to take the character in a new direction.  As is their prerogative.  It's their game.  I just don't like when people talk down to others for disliking a change.  And not so subtly implying they are wrong for liking what they liked before.  Aatrox was rewritten.  His personality did change.  Just because an idea wasn't completely detailed doesn't mean what was revealed wasn't there to begin with.
